title: Guðmundr
text:
Guðmundr (<a href="Old%20Norse">Old Norse</a>: , sometimes anglicised as Godmund) was a semi-legendary <a href="Norsemen">Norse</a> king in <a href="Jotunheim">Jotunheim</a>, ruling over a land called "<a href="Gl%C3%A6sisvellir">Glæsisvellir</a>", which was known as the warrior's paradise.
Guðmundr appears in the following <a href="legendary%20saga">legendary saga</a>s:
He also appears in <a href="Saxo%20Grammaticus">Saxo Grammaticus</a>' "<a href="Gesta%20Danorum">Gesta Danorum</a>" (Book VIII) and in "<a href="Samsons%20saga%20fagra">Samsons saga fagra</a>", one of the <a href="chivalric%20sagas">chivalric sagas</a>.
Guðmundr shared the same name with his father; "<a href="%C3%9Alfh%C3%A9%C3%B0inn">Úlfhéðinn</a>" was added to the son's name to differentiate father from son. According to some sources, Guðmundr Úlfhéðinn's son was <a href="Hei%C3%B0rekr">Heiðrekr</a> Úlfhamr. However, in "<a href="Hervarar%20saga%20ok%20Hei%C3%B0reks">Hervarar saga ok Heiðreks</a>" Guðmundr's son was <a href="H%C3%B6fund">Höfund</a>, who married <a href="Hervor">Hervor</a>, and their sons were <a href="Angant%C3%BDr">Angantýr</a> and <a href="Hei%C3%B0rekr">Heiðrekr</a>. <a href="Saxo%20Grammaticus">Saxo Grammaticus</a>, in "<a href="Gesta%20Danorum">Gesta Danorum</a>" , referred to Guðmundr Ulfheðinn as "Guthmundus", calling him a giant and the brother of "Geruthus" (<a href="Geirr%C3%B6%C3%B0r">Geirröðr</a>).
He is sometimes given the epithet "faxi", 'the one with a mane', i.e., a horse. This suggests a connection with the army of the dead who roam Norway at <a href="Yule">Yule</a>, the "<a href="Oskorei">Oskorei</a>". <a href="Otto%20H%C3%B6fler">Otto Höfler</a>, drawing on earlier theories of Nils Lid, argued that it was actually a word found in modern Norwegian dialect as both "fax" and "faxe" and referring to a kind of grass, and that it referred to the fertility symbol of the sheaf in Norwegian Yule celebrations. According to "Hervarar saga ok Heiðreks", the Norwegians came to see Guðmundr as a god; Höfler argued that in both the wolf-form suggested by "Úlfhéðinn" and the horse-form suggested by "faxi", Guðmundr was a death-demon and his death-horse the prototype of the death-horse <a href="Sleipnir">Sleipnir</a> portrayed on the <a href="Picture%20stone">Gotland picture stone</a>s. 
Ingemar Nordgren regards the first Guðmundr as "a cult-god" and his son, the Guðmundr of the sagas, as portraying him in <a href="theriomorphic">theriomorphic</a> form, and suggests that he is either an earlier fertility god who came to be identified with <a href="%C3%93%C3%B0inn">Óðinn</a> and that Glæsisvellir was influenced by <a href="Valhalla">Valhalla</a>, or that he is a local variant of a precursor of Óðinn.
Guðmundr and the <a href="Lombards">Lombards</a> are said to have battled <a href="Helgi">Helgi</a> and <a href="Sinfj%C3%B6tli">Sinfjötli</a>; it is Guðmundr who engages in the <a href="flyting">flyting</a> with Sinfjötli from shore in <a href="Helgakvi%C3%B0a%20Hundingsbana%20I">Helgakviða Hundingsbana I</a>. The latter are called the <a href="Ylfing">Ylfing</a>s, the 'wolf clan'. As Höfler noted, both armies are spoken of as animals, and <a href="Paulus%20Diaconus">Paulus Diaconus</a> identifies the Lombards with mares with white bands around their legs symbolising fetters (they did in fact bind their legs with white bands). Since Óðinn is patron of the Lombards, this is another Odinic connection.
<a href="Einar%20%C3%93lafur%20Sveinsson">Einar Ólafur Sveinsson</a> thought Guðmundr was Irish in origin while Geirröðr was native Scandinavian.
